awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2014 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Kathleen C. Craig is "Analysis and Numerics of Evolutionary Partial Differential Equations." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of California, Los Angeles, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Andrea Bertozzi.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Energy dissipation is a fundamental scientific principle, describing behavior throughout the natural world. A ball rolls down a hill to dissipate the potential energy induced by gravity; cells communicating via chemical signals move to minimize the ambient chemical potential. In certain systems, known as gradient flows, energy is not only dissipated, but the desire to dissipate energy as quickly as possible completely determines the system’s behavior. The present project studied gradient flows arising in physics, biology, and engineering through a unified approach combining mathematical analysis and numerical simulation. Significant results included new convexity methods for quantifying stability and new numerical methods for diffusive and height constrained systems.

 

This project has had broader impacts through the PI’s work to attract and retain more women in mathematics, as well as her work communicating mathematics to the general public. For example, the PI participated in UCSB’s Curie-osity Project, in which middle school girls visit the labs and offices of female scientists to learn about their research and career paths. The PI has also worked closely with UCSB’s chapter of the Association for Women in Mathematics, giving introductory lectures on her research to undergraduate and high school students.

 

The PI has also done outreach work aimed at communicating mathematics to the general public. Responding to a request from UCSB’s Department of Public Affairs, she helped create a 60 second video in honor of pi day. Based on the success of this video, UCSB’s Summer Lecture Series invited the PI to give a public lecture on her research through their GRIT (Groundbreaking Research Innovative Technology) program. Both the pi day video and the public lecture have been published online by the Department of Public Affairs.
